articles.headline: Tensions Flare Between Iraq and Saudi Arabia in U.S. Coalition
articles.snippet: An exchange between Iraq and Saudi Arabia reflected the challenges facing the Obama administration as it tries to hold together a diverse coalition in the fight against the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: An exchange between Iraq and Saudi Arabia reflected the challenges facing the Obama administration as it tries to hold together a diverse coalition in the fight against the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A remarkable clash between two key American allies in the Middle East burst into the open here on Wednesday as the Iraqi prime minister publicly criticized the Saudi air campaign in Yemen and a top Saudi official retorted that there was “no logic to those remarks.”
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Preserving the Ghastly Inventory of Auschwitz
articles.snippet: The aim of the foundation maintaining the site of the concentration camp is “to preserve authenticity.” It is a moral stance with specific curatorial challenges.
articles.abstract: The aim of the foundation maintaining the site of the concentration camp is “to preserve authenticity.” It is a moral stance with specific curatorial challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSWIECIM, Poland — To visit Auschwitz is to find an unfathomable but strangely familiar place. After so many photographs and movies, books and personal testimonies, it is tempting to think of it as a movie-set death camp, the product of a gruesome cinematic imagination, and not the real thing.

articles.headline: Case Against Google May Be Undercut by Rapid Changes in Technology
articles.snippet: As the antitrust case against Microsoft showed, the giants that look most unbeatable can falter in ways that have nothing to do with the actions of government regulators.
articles.abstract: As the antitrust case against Microsoft showed, the giants that look most unbeatable can falter in ways that have nothing to do with the actions of government regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: The antitrust case against Google filed by European Union regulators on Wednesday will inevitably draw comparisons to the long-running prosecution of Microsoft, in which regulators on both sides of the Atlantic pursued the software giant for anticompetitive behavior.

articles.headline: Ruling Shields G.M. From Ignition Suits
articles.snippet: A federal bankruptcy judge ruled that the automaker that emerged from bankruptcy in 2009 is not liable for accidents tied to the defect that occurred before that time.
articles.abstract: A federal bankruptcy judge ruled that the automaker that emerged from bankruptcy in 2009 is not liable for accidents tied to the defect that occurred before that time.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal bankruptcy judge on Wednesday blocked most lawsuits against General Motors over a defective ignition switch that is tied to at least 84 deaths, sparing the automaker billions in claims and handing it a momentous victory as it tries to move past its gravest safety crisis.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Microsoft, Once an Antitrust Target, Is Now Google’s Regulatory Scold
articles.snippet: The European Union is accusing Google of abusing its dominance, and Microsoft has links with the three initial complainants that sparked the antitrust investigation.
articles.abstract: The European Union is accusing Google of abusing its dominance, and Microsoft has links with the three initial complainants that sparked the antitrust investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Not long ago, Microsoft was the scourge of European antitrust regulators.

articles.headline: In Test for Unions and Politicians, a Nationwide Protest on Pay
articles.snippet: For activists anticipating the 2016 presidential race, the minimum wage fight, and the challenge it poses to a system they say favors the rich, comes at a pivotal time.
articles.abstract: For activists anticipating the 2016 presidential race, the minimum wage fight, and the challenge it poses to a system they say favors the rich, comes at a pivotal time.
articles.lead_paragraph: The protest by tens of thousands of low-wage workers, students and activists in more than 200 American cities on Wednesday is the most striking effort to date in a two-and-a-half-year-old labor-backed movement that is testing the ability of unions to succeed in an economy populated by easily replaceable service sector workers.

articles.headline: NBC News Alters Account of Correspondent’s Kidnapping in Syria
articles.snippet: NBC News amended its report of the 2012 abduction in Syria of Richard Engel, its chief foreign correspondent, saying Sunni militants were most likely to blame, not forces loyal to the Syrian president.
articles.abstract: NBC News amended its report of the 2012 abduction in Syria of Richard Engel, its chief foreign correspondent, saying Sunni militants were most likely to blame, not forces loyal to the Syrian president.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC News on Wednesday revised its account of the 2012 kidnapping of its chief foreign correspondent, Richard Engel, saying it was likely that Mr. Engel and his reporting team had been abducted by a Sunni militant group, not forces affiliated with the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.
articles.byline: By Ravi Somaiya, C. J. Chivers and Karam Shoumali

articles.headline: Ben Bernanke Will Work With Citadel, a Hedge Fund, as an Adviser
articles.snippet: The move by the former Federal Reserve chairman is the latest by a Washington insider through the revolving door into the financial industry.
articles.abstract: The move by the former Federal Reserve chairman is the latest by a Washington insider through the revolving door into the financial industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: For eight years, Ben S. Bernanke, the former Federal Reserve chairman, was steward of the world’s largest economy. Now he has signed on to advise one of Wall Street’s biggest hedge funds.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: A Century After Armenian Genocide, Turkey’s Denial Only Deepens
articles.snippet: Nearly 1.5 million Armenians died at the hands of the Ottoman Empire in 1915, during World War I. Turks by and large do not believe mass killings were planned.
articles.abstract: Nearly 1.5 million Armenians died at the hands of the Ottoman Empire in 1915, during World War I. Turks by and large do not believe mass killings were planned.
articles.lead_paragraph: CUNGUS, Turkey — The crumbling stone monastery, built into the hillside, stands as a forlorn monument to an awful past. So, too, does the decaying church on the other side of this mountain village. Farther out, a crevice is sliced into the earth, so deep that peering into it, one sees only blackness. Haunting for its history, it was there that a century ago, an untold number of Armenians were tossed to their deaths.

articles.headline: China Halts New Policy on Tech for Banks
articles.snippet: The rules, which called for companies that sell computer equipment to reveal secret code, have been at the center of a trade conflict with the United States.
articles.abstract: The rules, which called for companies that sell computer equipment to reveal secret code, have been at the center of a trade conflict with the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China has suspended a policy that would have effectively pushed foreign technology companies out of the country’s banking sector, according to a note sent by Chinese regulators to banks.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Vatican Ends Battle With U.S. Catholic Nuns’ Group
articles.snippet: An investigation and oversight of the nuns’ main leadership group, begun under Pope Benedict XVI, ended with an “expression of appreciation” from Pope Francis.
articles.abstract: An investigation and oversight of the nuns’ main leadership group, begun under Pope Benedict XVI, ended with an “expression of appreciation” from Pope Francis.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Vatican has abruptly ended its takeover of the main leadership group of American nuns two years earlier than expected, allowing Pope Francis to put to rest a confrontation started by his predecessor that created an uproar among American Catholics who had rallied to the sisters’ defense.

articles.headline: Etsy I.P.O. Tests Pledge to Balance Social Mission and Profit
articles.snippet: As a public company, Etsy is expected to face scrutiny from investors on how much it prioritizes its noble pursuits over its bottom line.
articles.abstract: As a public company, Etsy is expected to face scrutiny from investors on how much it prioritizes its noble pursuits over its bottom line.
articles.lead_paragraph: The online craft bazaar Etsy made its debut on the Nasdaq stock market Thursday, signaling the birth of an unusual public corporation — and not just because its employees carry around compost on bicycles, or because its regulatory filings are peppered with phrases like, “We keep it real, always.”

articles.headline: Jackpots for Local TV Stations in F.C.C. Auction of Airwaves
articles.snippet: The Federal Communications Commission is trying to persuade hundreds of TV stations to part with some of the most desirable airwaves, which would be acquired by mobile providers.
articles.abstract: The Federal Communications Commission is trying to persuade hundreds of TV stations to part with some of the most desirable airwaves, which would be acquired by mobile providers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The pitch to television broadcasters this week was not easy for them to swallow. It is a good time, they were told, to sell their most precious resource.
